conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light. The size and position of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast on the ground by the objects above the slabs.

premise: When the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
conclusion: This change affects both the position and the size of the shadows.

premise: As the light source moves backward, the angle of light relative to the objects decreases.
conclusion: This causes the shadows to shift backward, away from the objects.

premise: With the light source moving backward, the shadows will become longer.
conclusion: The increased distance between the light source and the objects results in a more elongated shadow.

premise: When the light source moves backward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become longer.
conclusion: The shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward, away from the objects and become longer.
